text: Man I am like a season and half behind on DW. I like Capaldi because I love grumpy old person doctor, but most of the scripts were just so bad.
Maybe I'll try to pull some highlights and start watching again with the clean slate of the new doctor

Anyone have any good places they go to for email inspiration? Doing an abandoned cart email and need to find some awesome things. I usually look around <http://reallygoodemails.com|reallygoodemails.com> and themeforest, any others?
Also, anyone use a good email framework for coded emails?
I use foundation for emails, hands down most amazing framework for email I’ve used
<@U7SL518D6> do you still send them through HS? I had major issues the last time I tried, something about HS not supporting a certain kind of table tag.
but that was easily over a year ago

For inspiration I look to the litmus blog a lot, they throw contests every now and again to push the limits of html email
This html email pinball machine will blow your mind <https://litmus.com/community/discussions/980-community-contest-creative-use-of-alt-text#comment-3418>
sorry linked to space invaders one, that ones better than the pinball

I do send through HS. and I did figure out that trusting the foundation for emails inliner is better than trusting HubSpots. I learned basically you want to build the email locally and basically just pop your finished code into HS and make different elements fields.

and you don't have to run them through any kind of conversion process or anything outside compiling... interesting. Will definitely take another look then, as I loved the local experience. (Also, I find it funny the one thing I don't use coded templates for, you do lol)
haha

yea I came from having to do html email templates like 3 times a week at my previous job to doing them like once to twice a month at my current job.

I don’t like the way HubSpot’s drag and drop template builder does emails (haven’t used the new beta email builder thing though)
im going to start with the sass version now, ill look to try and get it all setup
I actually won a battle with marketers saying that their emails should ideally be simple and in one column, once they agreed to that we went with the drag and drop and never looked back.
but now I'm tempted..... lol

Some other great resources -<http://responsiveemailpatterns.com/>
<https://email.geeks.chat/>
The chat one is a slack channel with basically all of the top HTML email devs out there. people from Mailchimp, Litmus, Google, etc
hey man, if you can convince them of that don’t go back lol
amen, that's what side projects are for buddy lol

yea, I honestly enjoy doing html emails sometimes, but really only if I don’t have to answer to a designer on it - because I will happily tell a client. “that 1px difference in outlook is what you get, outlook sucks.”

my all time favorite bizzare outlook quirk.

Had an email that had a really tall image.  every email client rendered it fine except outlook. Outlook weirdly after something like 1000px cut the image in two, and inserted an 800px gap or so.

I figured out the issue and it was the most hilariously bizzare thing ever
Last time i did any kind of email coding was two years ago so to have to do it now, I cant stand it, way to many variables to look out for.
When i asked them "Well, whats the top email clients from their previous vendor?" i got met with a i dont know and not sure why it matters
ummm because that helps gauge what to build for...?
i aint going worry about AOL if people dont freaking use it
heh yea
basically if you use foundation for emails - for everything the framework does your code will be cross compatible. anything you add on top of that you’re going to start needing to thoroughly test
oh and friendly reminder if you need to use margin, `Margin:10px;` capitalize the M. it’s stupid and obscure but will prevent tears and broken computers when testing outlook

but yea that outlook image issue. was caused by the fact outlook uses Microsoft Word’s rendering engine.

What happens if you put an image on a page in Microsoft word and the image is bigger than a page?

It splits the image in two separating the image onto two pages.

That image that was over 1000px tall was over ~9.5 inches tall (the default page content area in Microsoft word(11 inches minus the default margins))
Thus my image was ending up on a “new page” in outlook….. :face_palm:
Only in Microsoft land would inches matter in an email lol

Also a good resource - <http://litmus.com|litmus.com>
It’s expensive but worth every single cent.

When we’re tasked with a custom html email we figure the litmus cost into our price
Yes! I love litmus, I pushed that as well for this but they didn't want to go that route just yet.
I basically try to tell clients - either we litmus test or you’re likely going to have to compromise and accept it wont be pixel perfect in some email clients
HubSpot uses litmus for those test screenshots but it’s just not nearly as useful as the tools Litmus directly provides
